analysis.grammar: Disjointed letter - meaning known only to Allah
analysis.function: Opening letter of uncertain meaning
analysis.notes: One of 29 surahs that begin with mysterious letters. Scholars have various interpretations but the true meaning is known only to Allah.

analysis.grammar: Disjointed letter - meaning known only to Allah
analysis.function: Opening letter of uncertain meaning
analysis.notes: Second of three mysterious opening letters

analysis.grammar: Disjointed letter - meaning known only to Allah
analysis.function: Opening letter of uncertain meaning
analysis.notes: Third of three mysterious opening letters

ayat.arabic: ذَٰلِكَ الْكِتَابُ لَا رَيْبَ فِيهِ هُدًى لِلْمُتَّقِينَ
ayat.transliteration: Dhālika al-kitābu lā rayba fīhi hudan lil-muttaqīn
ayat.translation: This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah

analysis.grammar: Singular demonstrative pointing to something distant or of high status
analysis.function: Subject - points to the Quran
analysis.notes: Used for distant or elevated things. Here 'that' emphasizes the elevated status of the Quran, not physical distance.

analysis.function: Predicate - identifies what 'that' refers to
analysis.notes: From root k-t-b meaning 'to write'. Al-Kitāb specifically refers to the Quran as THE Book par excellence.

analysis.function: Negates existence of doubt
analysis.notes: Strong negation - 'lā' when used before indefinite nouns creates categorical negation, meaning 'there is absolutely no...'

analysis.function: Negated entity - what does not exist in the Book
analysis.notes: Rayb means doubt, suspicion, or uncertainty. The accusative case here is governed by the negative particle 'lā'.

analysis.function: Locative - specifies where there is no doubt (in the Book itself)
analysis.notes: فِي means 'in/within'. The attached pronoun ـهِ refers back to al-kitāb (the Book). Together: 'in it'.

analysis.function: Predicate or second subject - describes what the Book is
analysis.notes: From root h-d-y meaning 'to guide'. Hudā is guidance that leads to the right path. The tanween (un) indicates indefinite form, emphasizing the quality of guidance.

words.translation: for those conscious of Allah / for the righteous

analysis.case: Genitive (preposition governs genitive, indicated by yā ending in sound masculine plural)
analysis.function: Benefactive - specifies for whom the guidance is intended
analysis.notes: لِ means 'for'. Al-muttaqīn is active participle (Form VIII) from root w-q-y meaning 'to protect/guard'. Muttaqīn = those who protect themselves (from Allah's punishment by being conscious of Him). The ـينَ ending indicates masculine sound plural in genitive/accusative case.

ayat.arabic: الَّذِينَ يُؤْمِنُونَ بِالْغَيْبِ وَيُقِيمُونَ الصَّلَاةَ وَمِمَّا رَزَقْنَاهُمْ يُنْفِقُونَ
ayat.transliteration: Alladhīna yu'minūna bil-ghaybi wa-yuqīmūna aṣ-ṣalāta wa-mimmā razaqnāhum yunfiqūn
ayat.translation: Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them

analysis.function: Relative pronoun defining/describing al-muttaqīn from previous verse
analysis.notes: Alladhīna connects this verse to the previous, further describing 'al-muttaqīn'. It introduces a relative clause explaining WHO these God-conscious people are.

analysis.grammar: Present tense verb with attached plural subject pronoun
analysis.function: Main verb - describes the action of believing
analysis.notes: From root ʾ-m-n meaning 'to be safe/secure', Form IV means 'to believe/have faith'. The prefix يُـ (yu) indicates third person, suffix ـونَ (ūna) indicates masculine plural. Present tense implies continuous, habitual belief.

analysis.grammar: Preposition بِ + definite noun in genitive
analysis.case: Genitive (governed by preposition, indicated by kasra/i)
analysis.function: Object of belief - what they believe in
analysis.notes: بِ means 'in/with'. Al-ghayb from root gh-y-b means 'the unseen/hidden'. Refers to belief in Allah, angels, Day of Judgment, and matters beyond physical perception.

analysis.grammar: Coordinating conjunction وَ + present tense verb with plural subject
analysis.function: Coordinated verb - second action that defines al-muttaqīn
analysis.notes: وَ means 'and'. Yuqīmūna from root q-w-m (to stand/establish), Form IV means 'to establish, maintain, perform properly'. Not just 'pray' but establish prayer with all its conditions.

analysis.grammar: Definite noun, direct object of verb
analysis.case: Accusative (object of verb, indicated by fatha/a)
analysis.function: Direct object - what is being established
analysis.notes: From root ṣ-l-w meaning 'to pray/bless'. Aṣ-ṣalāh refers to the five daily ritual prayers, one of the five pillars of Islam.

analysis.function: Introduces the source of their spending
analysis.notes: وَ = 'and'. مِنْ = 'from' (becomes مِمَّ when attached to مَا). مَا = 'what/that which'. Together: 'and from what...'. The مِنْ indicates partitive meaning - they spend 'from' (some of) what they have.

analysis.grammar: Past tense verb with attached subject pronoun (نَا) and object pronoun (هُمْ)
analysis.person: First person plural (We - Allah using royal/majestic plural)
analysis.function: Relative clause verb describing the provision given to them
analysis.notes: From root r-z-q meaning 'to provide/sustain'. Razaqa = 'provided/gave sustenance'. نَا = 'We' (attached subject pronoun). هُمْ = 'them' (attached object pronoun). Allah is the Provider of all sustenance.

analysis.grammar: Present tense verb with plural subject pronoun
analysis.function: Main verb - third characteristic of al-muttaqīn
analysis.notes: From root n-f-q meaning 'to spend/expend'. Form IV yunfiqūna means 'they spend (in charity, for good causes)'. Emphasizes voluntary charitable spending beyond obligatory zakah, demonstrating generosity with Allah's provisions.

ayat.arabic: وَالَّذِينَ يُؤْمِنُونَ بِمَا أُنْزِلَ إِلَيْكَ وَمَا أُنْزِلَ مِنْ قَبْلِكَ وَبِالْآخِرَةِ هُمْ يُوقِنُونَ
ayat.transliteration: Walladhīna yu'minūna bimā unzila ilayka wa-mā unzila min qablika wa-bil-ākhirati hum yūqinūn
ayat.translation: And who believe in what has been revealed to you, and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain

analysis.function: Continues description of believers, coordinating with previous verse
analysis.notes: Continues the description of al-muttaqīn, adding another characteristic of the God-conscious.

analysis.grammar: Present tense verb with plural subject
analysis.function: Main verb - action of believing
analysis.notes: Same verb as in verse 3, emphasizing continuous belief.

analysis.function: Introduces the object of belief
analysis.notes: بِمَا together means 'in what' or 'in that which', introducing the content of their belief.

analysis.function: Passive verb describing revelation being sent down
analysis.notes: From root n-z-l meaning 'to descend'. Form IV passive unzila = 'was sent down/revealed'. Refers to divine revelation (the Quran) sent down from Allah.

analysis.function: Prepositional phrase indicating recipient of revelation
analysis.notes: إِلَى means 'to/toward'. كَ is second person singular masculine pronoun 'you'. Refers to Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) as recipient of the Quran.

analysis.function: Coordinates and introduces second object of belief
analysis.notes: وَ = 'and', مَا = 'what'. Together introduces the second part: previous revelations.

analysis.function: Passive verb - repeated from previous
analysis.notes: Same verb repeated, now referring to previous scriptures (Torah, Gospel, Psalms, etc.) revealed to earlier prophets.

analysis.function: Indicates time reference - 'from before'
analysis.case: Governs genitive case on following word
analysis.notes: مِنْ here has temporal meaning, indicating 'from' a previous time period.

analysis.case: Genitive (governed by مِنْ, indicated by kasra/i)
analysis.function: Temporal phrase - indicates time before the Prophet
analysis.mudaf_mudaf_ilayhi: قَبْلِ is mudaf, كَ (you) is mudaf ilayhi
analysis.notes: قَبْلِ means 'before'. كَ = 'you' (possessive pronoun). Together: 'before you', referring to revelations given to prophets before Muhammad (ﷺ).

analysis.case: Genitive (governed by preposition, indicated by kasra/i and tāʾ marbūṭa)
analysis.function: Prepositional phrase - third object of belief
analysis.notes: وَ = 'and'. بِ = 'in'. الْآخِرَة from root ʾ-kh-r meaning 'last/final'. Al-ākhirah = 'the Hereafter/Last Day'. Refers to belief in the Day of Judgment, afterlife, Paradise, and Hell.

analysis.function: Subject pronoun for emphasis
analysis.notes: Independent pronoun used for emphasis. Emphasizes that THEY (specifically) have certainty about the Hereafter.

analysis.grammar: Present tense verb with plural subject
analysis.function: Main verb - describes their certainty
analysis.notes: From root y-q-n meaning 'to be certain/sure'. Form IV yūqinūna = 'they have certainty/conviction'. Higher level than regular belief (īmān) - absolute certainty with no doubt about the Hereafter.

ayat.arabic: أُولَٰئِكَ عَلَىٰ هُدًى مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ وَأُولَٰئِكَ هُمُ الْمُفْلِحُونَ
ayat.transliteration: Ulāʾika ʿalā hudan min rabbihim wa-ulāʾika humu al-mufliḥūn
ayat.translation: Those are upon guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful

analysis.grammar: Plural demonstrative pronoun for distant/elevated things
analysis.function: Subject - refers back to the believers described in verses 3-4
analysis.notes: Ulāʾika is plural form of dhālika. Used to point to people with elevated status. Refers to all the believers who have the qualities mentioned in verses 2-4.

analysis.function: Indicates being established upon guidance
analysis.case: Governs genitive case on following word
analysis.notes: عَلَى means 'upon/on'. Here used metaphorically to indicate being firmly established upon guidance.

analysis.case: Genitive (governed by عَلَى, but appears nominative with tanween due to defective noun ending in alif maqsura)
analysis.function: Object of preposition - what they are upon
analysis.notes: Same word as in verse 2. Here indicates the state of being guided. The indefiniteness suggests complete, perfect guidance.

analysis.function: Indicates the source of guidance
analysis.case: Governs genitive case on following word
analysis.notes: مِنْ indicates source - the guidance comes FROM their Lord, not from themselves.

analysis.case: Genitive (governed by مِنْ, indicated by kasra/i)
analysis.function: Source of guidance
analysis.mudaf_mudaf_ilayhi: رَبِّ is mudaf, هِمْ (their) is mudaf ilayhi
analysis.notes: رَبّ from root r-b-b means 'Lord/Master/Sustainer/Nurturer'. هِمْ = 'their' (possessive pronoun). Emphasizes personal relationship between believers and their Lord.

analysis.function: Subject of second clause, emphasizing same group
analysis.notes: Repetition of ulāʾika for emphasis, introducing a second declaration about these believers.

analysis.function: Pronoun of separation (damir al-fasl) for emphasis and restriction
analysis.notes: Used here as pronoun of separation (damir al-fasl). Emphasizes and restricts the meaning: THEY (and specifically they) are the successful ones.

analysis.function: Predicate - describes the believers as successful
analysis.notes: From root f-l-ḥ meaning 'to succeed/prosper/thrive'. Form IV active participle al-mufliḥūn = 'the successful ones/those who achieve success'. Refers to ultimate success: Paradise in the Hereafter. The definite article + restriction by damir al-fasl emphasizes they are THE ONLY truly successful ones.

metadata.longest_verse: Verse 282 (129 words) - Ayat al-Dayn (Verse of Debt)
metadata.famous_verse: Verse 255 - Ayat al-Kursi (Verse of the Throne)
metadata.notes: Al-Baqarah is the longest surah in the Quran. These first 5 verses introduce the Quran and describe the characteristics of the muttaqīn (God-conscious believers).
